bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 5, 1919

div1.p: Carter reflects, at length, on his career in public medicine and his accomplishments.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 5, 1919
div1.opener:
Do you know I wish much that I had included my
footnote about Finlay in my Y. F. article & given
Byam his choice of accepting it including
it or of throwing the whole thing out? He had taken it,
H.R.C.
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U.S. MARINE HOSPITAL
NEW ORLEANS, LA. May 5/19
My Dear Daughter:
div1.p:
This is the 40th anniversary of my appoint-
ment in the service. I took the oath about the 9th or 11th
the 9th I think

It is a long time to look back to & the service has certainly
grown. It had 34 medical officers then & practically no
sanitary functions. I had much-more than any other
field-officer-in the developing of these.

I am glad I joined. I don't think I have had as
happy a life as the average if I had stayed in private
practice - yet am I content. I have lived a satisfac-
tory life & a very full life: I have seen many things
& seen them clearly & entirely: I have taken part in
not a fun important things myself & some I have
done myself & of my own initiative. It has been
very full of interest & man somethings I have
enjoyed
2
enjoyed intensely- All of the early struggle
in the upbuilding of the national quarantine in which
I know we would-succeed- & in which we did; the
work on Extrinsic Incubation - after the groping
for a clue had been was over: the early work in Pan-
ama- say the first 2 years18 or 20 months during which I was
always as sure of success as I am now. I have fought
hopeless fights lost-fights & won them by shear de-
termination. but in most of my work I have felt
more than a hope- a certainty of success. I confess I
have not enjoyed the “gandium certaminis” as
much as a more aggressive man would have done.

My life work really began in Jan/88 at Ship Is-
land. The 9 years preceeding it had been about like
the life of any other man who was doing professional
work. I will say that I had never failed to give the best that
was in me to my patients. With Ship Island the sani-
tary problems presented themselves & on them I have
mainly been engaged- in research: exposition & exec-
utive - almost ever since

The malaria work sin 1912 I count in the above & it has
been on the whole good work, and capable of almost
indefinite expansion. That LePrince is with the ser-
vice in which he is more useful than he would be
anywhere else- I also count to my credit. I am
sorry for the delay & shilly shallying(?) about the
malaria this year I fear too from Williams opinion
that Fricks is not the man for the job. By the way a
decidedly able man is Louis & even if he draws out
from malaria. will still be a useful officer - as his fa-
ther has been. nevertheless I think he will miss his
highest efficiency. Bless Gertrude she is not worth
what she costs - i.e. is a social loss.

I was evidently the sicker that I thought but have been
up in a wheel chair, Saturday: yesterday & today & pre-
sume I will be able to learn with in a wish. I am con-
valescing fast, but have not attempted to walk- ex-
cept from the chair to the bed. The nursing here is better
than that in the private rooms at Hopkins. I expect that the
Pneumonia Vaccine saved my life. If it did anything it
4
did- Because after 31/2 days of considerable toxaemia I
developed a general Capillary Bronchitis with some; don't know how much, bronchopneumonia. Well it is over
& I only regret that I have lost so much time - over
4 weeks in all. Lord, I am glad that I have the
Atlantic City Article written.

I am very sorry for Henry's change of orders I
& he & your mother would have enjoyed his vi-
sit home, It is too far to come now I judge- although
he gets I think. a fare of 1 cent a mile, Too far however.
I fear.

Give my love to your mother & to Mary & Jennie & to
Gertrude if she be still with you.

The little Iris-the Crimean Iris-at the North end,
of the rows sh'd be in bloom now - although I
rather hope they wait until a week later.

This long letter written partly in bed & partly in the
wheel chair is proff proof. that I am quite strong
Hasta la Vista Querida Mia
